13.text:
There's a magnificent
idea by Steven Johnson.

16.text:
He says our thoughts
shape our spaces.

25.text:
He says, our spaces
return the favor.

30.text:
Those spaces we build, the
architecture of happiness,

33.text:
as Alain de Botton writes,
the spaces we create in turn

37.text:
inform, shape, sculpt our
subjective experience.

46.text:
We script intention
into our designs.

50.text:
And those designs,
in turn, script

56.text:
Our ability to create
virtual future possibilities,

59.text:
both for ourselves
and for others,

61.text:
to create future spaces,
to inform future thoughts,

66.text:
to build a thinking room,
to build an idea lab,

69.text:
to build a creative playground,
to build a backyard that's

73.text:
going evoke being a child
playing in the yard,

76.text:
I mean, even the space
we're in right now,

77.text:
the serene water, the perfect
temperature, the hue coming

81.text:
from that sky, the fact that
we went around the bend,

84.text:
we're surrounded by green,
there's no other way

86.text:
to enter the space
we're in, creates a kind

89.text:
of womb-like, serene
space, mood, reality,

94.text:
it's such a wild idea
because, again, going back

97.text:
to realize the freedom that
we have to compose our lives,

101.text:
what Timothy Leary calls the
"vertigo of freedom," right?

106.text: I can actually shape this thing?

108.text:
This chaotic ride is a blank
canvas for me to beautify?

116.text:
It's Henry Miller's
blade of grass

120.text:
becomes a magnificent
world in itself.

122.text: There is so much to inspire us.

125.text:
And to realize that we
are bound by no limits

130.text:
in order to drink that
inspiration, it's there

133.text:
for the taking, were
we to just exercise

136.text:
a little discretion,
a little discernment,

139.text:
flex those creative
muscles and make it happen,

143.text:
we engineer, literally,
our own divinity.
